title: Authors and Citation
text: Resul Akay. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Akay R (2026). caretForecast: Conformal Time Series Forecasting Using State Art Machine Learning Algorithms. R package version 0.1.2, https://akai01.github.io/caretForecast/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {caretForecast: Conformal Time Series Forecasting Using State of Art Machine Learning Algorithms},   author = {Resul Akay},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.1.2},   url = {https://akai01.github.io/caretForecast/}, }

title: caretForecast
text: caretForecast aspires equip users means using machine learning algorithms time series data forecasting.

title: caretForecast
text: Use regression model caret package time series forecasting Automatic feature engineering lagged values Fourier terms seasonality Horizon-specific conformal prediction intervals proper --sample calibration Support external regressors (promotions, holidays, etc.) Compatible hierarchical/grouped time series via hts package

title: caretForecast
text: CRAN version : development version GitHub :
code: install.packages("caretForecast") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("Akai01/caretForecast")

title: caretForecast
text: using caretForecast, users can train regression model compatible caret package. allows use machine learning model need order solve specific problems, shown examples .

title: caretForecast
code: library(caretForecast) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'quantmod': #>   method            from #>   as.zoo.data.frame zoo  data(retail_wide, package = "caretForecast")

title: caretForecast
code: i <- 8  dtlist <- caretForecast::split_ts(retail_wide[,i], test_size = 12)  training_data <- dtlist$train  testing_data <- dtlist$test  fit <- ARml(training_data, max_lag = 12, caret_method = "cubist",              verbose = FALSE) #> initial_window = NULL. Setting initial_window = 301 #> Loading required package: ggplot2 #> Loading required package: lattice  forecast(fit, h = length(testing_data), level = c(80,95))-> fc  accuracy(fc, testing_data) #>                     ME      RMSE       MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set 0.3616104  8.550244  6.349603 -0.0727533 3.243307 0.4120175 #> Test set     2.4886342 15.770333 11.247363  1.1450840 3.448918 0.7298268 #>                   ACF1 Theil's U #> Training set 0.2754280        NA #> Test set     0.3447055 0.5827831   autoplot(fc) +    autolayer(testing_data, series = "testing_data")

title: caretForecast
code: i <- 9  dtlist <- caretForecast::split_ts(retail_wide[,i], test_size = 12)  training_data <- dtlist$train  testing_data <- dtlist$test  fit <- ARml(training_data, max_lag = 12, caret_method = "cubist",              verbose = FALSE) #> initial_window = NULL. Setting initial_window = 301  forecast(fit, h = length(testing_data), level = c(80,95), PI = TRUE)-> fc  accuracy(fc, testing_data) #>                       ME     RMSE      MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set   0.5498926 13.33516 10.36501  0.0394589 2.223005 0.3454108 #> Test set     -17.9231242 47.13871 32.03537 -2.6737257 4.271373 1.0675691 #>                   ACF1 Theil's U #> Training set 0.3979153        NA #> Test set     0.4934659 0.4736043  autoplot(fc) +    autolayer(testing_data, series = "testing_data")

what: Forecasting using Support Vector Machines with Linear Kernel
title: caretForecast
code: i <- 9  dtlist <- caretForecast::split_ts(retail_wide[,i], test_size = 12)  training_data <- dtlist$train  testing_data <- dtlist$test  fit <- ARml(training_data, max_lag = 12, caret_method = "svmLinear2",              verbose = FALSE, pre_process = c("scale", "center")) #> initial_window = NULL. Setting initial_window = 301  forecast(fit, h = length(testing_data), level = c(80,95), PI = TRUE)-> fc  accuracy(fc, testing_data) #>                      ME     RMSE      MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set -0.2227708 22.66741 17.16009 -0.2476916 3.712496 0.5718548 #> Test set     -1.4732653 28.47932 22.92438 -0.4787467 2.883937 0.7639481 #>                   ACF1 Theil's U #> Training set 0.3290937        NA #> Test set     0.3863955 0.3137822  autoplot(fc) +    autolayer(testing_data, series = "testing_data") get_var_imp(fc) get_var_imp(fc, plot = F) #> loess r-squared variable importance #>  #>   only 20 most important variables shown (out of 23) #>  #>        Overall #> lag12 100.0000 #> lag1   83.9153 #> lag11  80.4644 #> lag2   79.9170 #> lag3   79.5019 #> lag4   78.3472 #> lag9   78.1634 #> lag5   78.0262 #> lag7   77.9153 #> lag8   76.7721 #> lag10  76.4275 #> lag6   75.7056 #> S1-12   3.8169 #> S3-12   2.4230 #> C2-12   2.1863 #> S5-12   2.1154 #> C4-12   1.9426 #> C1-12   0.5974 #> C6-12   0.3883 #> S2-12   0.2220

title: caretForecast
code: i <- 8  dtlist <- caretForecast::split_ts(retail_wide[,i], test_size = 12)  training_data <- dtlist$train  testing_data <- dtlist$test  fit <- ARml(training_data, max_lag = 12, caret_method = "ridge",              verbose = FALSE) #> initial_window = NULL. Setting initial_window = 301  forecast(fit, h = length(testing_data), level = c(80,95), PI = TRUE)-> fc  accuracy(fc, testing_data) #>                       ME     RMSE      MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set 7.11464e-14 12.69082  9.53269 -0.1991292 5.212444 0.6185639 #> Test set     1.52445e+00 14.45469 12.04357  0.6431543 3.880894 0.7814914 #>                   ACF1 Theil's U #> Training set 0.2598784        NA #> Test set     0.3463574 0.5056792  autoplot(fc) +    autolayer(testing_data, series = "testing_data") get_var_imp(fc) get_var_imp(fc, plot = F) #> loess r-squared variable importance #>  #>   only 20 most important variables shown (out of 23) #>  #>        Overall #> lag12 100.0000 #> lag1   84.2313 #> lag2   78.9566 #> lag11  78.5354 #> lag3   76.3480 #> lag10  74.4727 #> lag4   74.1330 #> lag7   74.0737 #> lag9   73.9113 #> lag5   73.2040 #> lag8   72.7224 #> lag6   71.5713 #> S1-12   6.3658 #> S3-12   2.7341 #> C2-12   2.7125 #> S5-12   2.4858 #> C4-12   2.2137 #> C6-12   0.6381 #> C1-12   0.5176 #> S2-12   0.4464

title: caretForecast
text: xreg argument can used adding promotions, holidays, external variables model. example , add seasonal dummies model. set ‘seasonal = FALSE’ avoid adding Fourier series model together seasonal dummies.
code: xreg_train <- forecast::seasonaldummy(AirPassengers)  newxreg <- forecast::seasonaldummy(AirPassengers, h = 21)  fit <- ARml(AirPassengers, max_lag = 4, caret_method = "cubist",              seasonal = FALSE, xreg = xreg_train, verbose = FALSE) #> initial_window = NULL. Setting initial_window = 132  fc <- forecast(fit, h = 12, level = c(80, 95, 99), xreg = newxreg)  autoplot(fc) get_var_imp(fc)

title: caretForecast
text: version 0.1.2, caretForecast implements horizon-specific conformal prediction intervals. approach provides properly calibrated prediction intervals naturally widen forecast horizon (trumpet shape), addressing common limitation ML-based forecasting methods.

title: caretForecast
text: calibrate = TRUE (default), ARml() performs rolling-origin calibration using --sample forecasts compute nonconformity scores forecast horizon. ensures prediction intervals correct coverage probability.

title: caretForecast
text: calibrate: Logical. TRUE (default), performs horizon-specific calibration conformal prediction intervals calibration_horizon: Maximum forecast horizon calibration. Defaults 2 * frequency(y) seasonal data 10 non-seasonal data n_cal_windows: Number rolling windows calibration. Automatically determined based data length (max 50)

title: caretForecast
code: # Fit model with conformal calibration (default) fit <- ARml(AirPassengers, max_lag = 12, caret_method = "ridge",             verbose = FALSE, calibrate = TRUE) #> initial_window = NULL. Setting initial_window = 124  # Forecast with prediction intervals fc <- forecast(fit, h = 24, level = c(80, 95))  # The intervals widen appropriately with forecast horizon autoplot(fc)

what: Autoregressive forecasting using various Machine Learning models. — ARml
title: Autoregressive forecasting using various Machine Learning models. — ARml
text: Autoregressive forecasting using various Machine Learning models.

title: Autoregressive forecasting using various Machine Learning models. — ARml
code: ARml(   y,   max_lag = 5,   xreg = NULL,   caret_method = "cubist",   metric = "RMSE",   pre_process = NULL,   cv = TRUE,   cv_horizon = 4,   initial_window = NULL,   fixed_window = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   seasonal = TRUE,   K = frequency(y)/2,   tune_grid = NULL,   lambda = NULL,   BoxCox_method = c("guerrero", "loglik"),   BoxCox_lower = -1,   BoxCox_upper = 2,   BoxCox_biasadj = FALSE,   BoxCox_fvar = NULL,   allow_parallel = FALSE,   calibrate = TRUE,   calibration_horizon = NULL,   n_cal_windows = NULL,   ... )

title: Autoregressive forecasting using various Machine Learning models. — ARml
text: y univariate time series object. max_lag Maximum value lag. xreg Optional. numerical vector matrix external regressors, must number rows y. (data frame.). caret_method string specifying classification regression model use. Possible values found using names(getModelInfo()). list functions can also passed custom model function. See http://topepo.github.io/caret/ details. metric string specifies summary metric used select optimal model. See ?caret::train. pre_process string vector defines pre-processing predictor data. Current possibilities "BoxCox", "YeoJohnson", "expoTrans", "center", "scale", "range", "knnImpute", "bagImpute", "medianImpute", "pca", "ica" "spatialSign". default pre-processing. See preProcess trainControl procedures adjust . Pre-processing code designed work x simple matrix data frame. cv Logical, cv = TRUE model selection done via cross-validation. cv = FALSE user need provide specific model via tune_grid argument. cv_horizon number consecutive values test set sample. initial_window initial number consecutive values training set sample. fixed_window Logical, FALSE, training samples start 1. verbose logical printing training log. seasonal Boolean. seasonal = TRUE fourier terms used modeling seasonality. K Maximum order(s) Fourier terms tune_grid data frame possible tuning values. columns named tuning parameters. Use getModelInfo get list tuning parameters model see http://topepo.github.io/caret/available-models.html. (NOTE: given, argument must named.) lambda BoxCox transformation parameter. lambda = NULL lambda = "auto", transformation parameter lambda chosen using BoxCox.lambda. BoxCox_method BoxCox.lambda argument. Choose method used calculating lambda. BoxCox_lower BoxCox.lambda argument. Lower limit possible lambda values. BoxCox_upper BoxCox.lambda argument. Upper limit possible lambda values. BoxCox_biasadj InvBoxCox argument. Use adjusted back-transformed mean Box-Cox transformations. transformed data used produce forecasts fitted values, regular back transformation result median forecasts. biasadj TRUE, adjustment made produce mean forecasts fitted values. BoxCox_fvar InvBoxCox argument. Optional parameter required biasadj=TRUE. Can either forecast variance, list containing interval level, corresponding upper lower intervals. allow_parallel parallel backend loaded available, function use ? calibrate Logical. TRUE, performs rolling-origin calibration compute horizon-specific conformal prediction intervals. produces properly calibrated intervals widen forecast horizon (trumpet shape). Default TRUE. calibration_horizon Maximum forecast horizon calibration. NULL (default), uses 2 * frequency(y) seasonal data 10 non-seasonal data. n_cal_windows Number rolling windows calibration. NULL (default), automatically determined based data length (max 50). ... Ignored.

title: Autoregressive forecasting using various Machine Learning models. — ARml
text: list class forecast containing following elemets x : input time series method : name forecasting method character string mean : Point forecasts time series lower : Lower limits prediction intervals upper : Upper limits prediction intervals level : confidence values associated prediction intervals model : list containing information fitted model newx : matrix containing regressors calibration : Horizon-specific conformal calibration scores (calibrate=TRUE)

title: Autoregressive forecasting using various Machine Learning models. — ARml
text: Resul Akay

title: Autoregressive forecasting using various Machine Learning models. — ARml
code: library(caretForecast)  train_data <- window(AirPassengers, end = c(1959, 12))  test <- window(AirPassengers, start = c(1960, 1))  ARml(train_data, caret_method = "lm", max_lag = 12) -> fit #> initial_window = NULL. Setting initial_window = 112 #> Loading required package: ggplot2 #> Loading required package: lattice #> + Training112: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training112: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training113: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training113: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training114: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training114: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training115: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training115: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training116: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training116: intercept=TRUE  #> Aggregating results #> Fitting final model on full training set #> Performing horizon-specific calibration for conformal prediction intervals... #> Calibrating conformal scores using 34 rolling windows... #> Calibration complete. Samples per horizon: 34 to 34  forecast(fit, h = length(test)) -> fc  autoplot(fc) + autolayer(test)   accuracy(fc, test) #>                         ME     RMSE       MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set -6.039671e-15 10.19861  7.884296 -0.1380603 3.263387 0.2589260 #> Test set      5.515070e+00 19.71858 17.108979  0.8260714 3.540353 0.5618712 #>                    ACF1 Theil's U #> Training set 0.07296876        NA #> Test set     0.32299513 0.3864957

what: Perform rolling-origin calibration with recursive forecasting — calibrate_horizon_scores
title: Perform rolling-origin calibration with recursive forecasting — calibrate_horizon_scores
text: function computes horizon-specific nonconformity scores performing rolling-origin evaluation recursive multi-step forecasting. ensures proper --sample calibration respects exchangeability assumption required valid conformal prediction intervals.

title: Perform rolling-origin calibration with recursive forecasting — calibrate_horizon_scores
code: calibrate_horizon_scores(   y,   y_modified,   max_lag,   caret_method,   seasonal,   K,   lambda,   pre_process,   tune_grid,   xreg = NULL,   calibration_horizon,   n_windows = NULL,   initial_window = NULL,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Perform rolling-origin calibration with recursive forecasting — calibrate_horizon_scores
text: y Original time series (untransformed) y_modified Transformed time series (Box-Cox applicable) max_lag Maximum lag used model caret_method caret method name seasonal Logical, whether seasonal terms used K Fourier order seasonality lambda Box-Cox transformation parameter pre_process Pre-processing specification tune_grid Tuning grid (uses best parameters initial fit) xreg External regressors matrix (optional) calibration_horizon Maximum forecast horizon calibration n_windows Number rolling windows calibration initial_window Initial training window size calibration verbose Logical, print progress

title: Perform rolling-origin calibration with recursive forecasting — calibrate_horizon_scores
text: list horizon-indexed vectors sorted absolute errors

what: Fit a horizon-specific conformal regressor for time series forecasting. — conformalRegressorByHorizon
title: Fit a horizon-specific conformal regressor for time series forecasting. — conformalRegressorByHorizon
text: function creates conformal regressor accounts increasing uncertainty longer forecast horizons. uses separate nonconformity score distributions horizon h=1,2,3,..., resulting prediction intervals naturally widen forecast horizon increases (trumpet-shaped intervals).

title: Fit a horizon-specific conformal regressor for time series forecasting. — conformalRegressorByHorizon
code: conformalRegressorByHorizon(horizon_errors)

title: Fit a horizon-specific conformal regressor for time series forecasting. — conformalRegressorByHorizon
text: horizon_errors named list element contains sorted absolute errors horizon. Names "h1", "h2", etc. typically produced calibrate_horizon_scores().

title: Fit a horizon-specific conformal regressor for time series forecasting. — conformalRegressorByHorizon
text: conformalRegressorByHorizon object containing: alphas_by_horizon List sorted nonconformity scores horizon max_horizon Maximum calibrated horizon n_samples Number calibration samples per horizon

title: Fit a horizon-specific conformal regressor for time series forecasting. — conformalRegressorByHorizon
text: Boström, H., 2022. crepes: Python Package Generating Conformal Regressors Predictive Systems. Conformal Probabilistic Prediction Applications. PMLR, 179. https://copa-conference.com/papers/COPA2022_paper_11.pdf Stankeviciute, K., Alaa, . M., & van der Schaar, M., 2021. Conformal Time-series Forecasting. NeurIPS 2021.

title: Forecasting using ARml model — forecast.ARml
text: list class forecast containing following elemets x : input time series method : name forecasting method character string mean : Point forecasts time series lower : Lower limits prediction intervals upper : Upper limits prediction intervals level : confidence values associated prediction intervals model : list containing information fitted model newxreg : matrix containing regressors

title: Forecasting using ARml model — forecast.ARml
code: library(caretForecast)  train_data <- window(AirPassengers, end = c(1959, 12))  test <- window(AirPassengers, start = c(1960, 1))  ARml(train_data, caret_method = "lm", max_lag = 12) -> fit #> initial_window = NULL. Setting initial_window = 112 #> + Training112: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training112: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training113: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training113: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training114: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training114: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training115: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training115: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training116: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training116: intercept=TRUE  #> Aggregating results #> Fitting final model on full training set #> Performing horizon-specific calibration for conformal prediction intervals... #> Calibrating conformal scores using 34 rolling windows... #> Calibration complete. Samples per horizon: 34 to 34  forecast(fit, h = length(test), level = c(80,95)) -> fc  autoplot(fc)+ autolayer(test)   accuracy(fc, test) #>                         ME     RMSE       MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set -6.039671e-15 10.19861  7.884296 -0.1380603 3.263387 0.2589260 #> Test set      5.515070e+00 19.71858 17.108979  0.8260714 3.540353 0.5618712 #>                    ACF1 Theil's U #> Training set 0.07296876        NA #> Test set     0.32299513 0.3864957

code: train <- window(AirPassengers, end = c(1959, 12))  test <- window(AirPassengers, start = c(1960, 1))  ARml(train, caret_method = "lm", max_lag = 12, trend_method = "none",  pre_process = "center") -> fit #> initial_window = NULL. Setting initial_window = 112 #> + Training112: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training112: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training113: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training113: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training114: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training114: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training115: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training115: intercept=TRUE  #> + Training116: intercept=TRUE  #> - Training116: intercept=TRUE  #> Aggregating results #> Fitting final model on full training set #> Performing horizon-specific calibration for conformal prediction intervals... #> Calibrating conformal scores using 34 rolling windows... #> Calibration complete. Samples per horizon: 34 to 34  forecast(fit, h = length(test), level = c(80,95)) -> fc  autoplot(fc)+ autolayer(test)   accuracy(fc, test) #>                        ME     RMSE       MAE        MPE     MAPE      MASE #> Training set 3.434088e-15 10.19861  7.884296 -0.1380603 3.263387 0.2589260 #> Test set     5.515070e+00 19.71858 17.108979  0.8260714 3.540353 0.5618712 #>                    ACF1 Theil's U #> Training set 0.07296876        NA #> Test set     0.32299513 0.3864957  get_var_imp(fc, plot = TRUE)

title: caretForecast 0.1.2
text: Implemented horizon-specific conformal prediction intervals proper --sample calibration Added new parameters ARml(): calibrate, calibration_horizon, n_cal_windows New functions: conformalRegressorByHorizon(), calibrate_horizon_scores() Prediction intervals now properly widen forecast horizon (trumpet shape) Added comprehensive test suite short time series handling
